title: N (place) へ 行きます / 来ます / 帰ります
explanation: When a verb indicates movement to a certain place, the particle へ is used after the place noun to show the direction. It is pronounced え.

title: どこへも 行きません / 行きませんでした
explanation: When an interrogative takes a particle and the verb is negative, it denies all possibilities.

title: N (vehicle) で 行きます / 来ます / 帰ります
explanation: The particle で indicates a means or method. With verbs of movement, it marks the vehicle used. For walking, use あるいて without で.

examples.japanese: 駅から歩いて帰りました。
examples.english: I walked home from the station.

title: N (person/animal) と V
explanation: The particle と is used when doing something together with a person or animal. To say 'alone,' use ひとりで (without と).

examples.japanese: 家族と日本へ来ました。
examples.english: I came to Japan with my family.

examples.japanese: 一人で東京へ行きます。

title: いつ
explanation: いつ (when) is used to ask about time. Unlike なんじ or なんにち, it does not take に.

examples.japanese: いつ日本へ来ましたか。
examples.english: When did you come to Japan?

examples.japanese: いつ広島へ行きますか。
examples.english: When will you go to Hiroshima?

title: Sよ
explanation: よ is attached to the end of a sentence to emphasize information the listener doesn’t know, or to state your judgement assertively.

examples.japanese: この電車は甲子園へ行きますか。
examples.english: Does this train go to Koshien?

answer.japanese: いいえ、行きません。次の普通ですよ。
answer.english: No, it doesn’t. The next local train does.

examples.japanese: 無理なダイエットは体によくないですよ。
examples.english: Excessive dieting is bad for your health.
